reasoning: The critique targets one illustrative pathway in the essay (digital-being governance/voting dynamics) rather than the core multi-pronged case that eutopia is fragile due to many independent potential “single flaws” plus later technical arguments about value functions. So centrality is low-to-moderate: removing/weakening this example would only slightly broaden the alleged ‘narrow target.’ Strength is low because it mostly asserts that robust institutions could be designed, without engaging the essay’s conditioning on “no serious, coordinated efforts” or giving reasons to think such institutional robustness is likely by default; it also doesn’t address the broader point that even well-intentioned governance can fail under value disagreement, motivated reasoning, or power concentration. Still, it correctly notes a plausible mitigating possibility the essay should model, so correctness is fairly high though it somewhat overstates by implying the paper assumes catastrophe is likely rather than offering it as one risk among many. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Robust digital governance institutions could prevent moral lock-in from digital beings
